content:
Recent political changes in Brazil have had a significant impact on the country's economy. Brazil has experienced extensive political turmoil in recent years with a notable change in government in 2018, when Jair Bolsonaro was elected as president.

One of the major changes introduced by Bolsonaro was an extensive economic liberalization agenda, which led to the introduction of a wide range of economic policies aimed at streamlining business activity, reducing bureaucracy, and promoting foreign investment. Some of these policies include pension reform, labor market reform, tax reform, and privatization of state-owned enterprises.

Despite these changes, the economy contracted in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The pandemic hit Brazil hard, and the country suffered from high inflation, low consumer morale, and the uncertainty surrounding the global economy. The economy is expected to rebound in 2021, driven by government stimulus, increasing economic activity, and a rebounding global economy.

In summary, the recent political changes in Brazil have had a mixed impact on the country's economy. While the liberalization agenda has created a strong foundation for growth, external factors such as the COVID-19 pandemic have also impacted the economy significantly.
